speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: Chapter Four: The Voice Design Engine. I was created here. I am not a pre-trained speaker. I am a character the Voice Design engine assembled from a text description — an elderly man in his seventies, deep and gravelly, masculine and husky, with a rough, raspy texture.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: The Voice Design tab is marked in blue. Inside, you will find two text fields. The first is the Voice Description. This defines the physical body of the speaker — things like age, gender, vocal texture, and accent. These qualities stay consistent across every line you generate.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: The second field is the Style Instruction. This works exactly like it does in the Custom Voice tab. It controls how the speaker performs right now — their emotion, pace, and energy. You can change this between takes without altering the underlying voice.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: When you find a combination you like, click Save Profile. Give it a name, and it will be stored as a reusable Voice Design Profile. You can load it from the dropdown at the top of the tab to instantly restore both the description and the style.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: If you have the Style and Profile Manager plugin enabled, it adds a dedicated tab where you can browse, edit, enable, and disable all your saved styles and profiles in one place. Disabled items are hidden from the dropdowns without being deleted.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: There is also a useful trick for locking in a Voice Design voice. Generate a line you love, save it as a W A V from the Session History, then load that W A V into the Voice Clone tab as a reference. The Clone engine can then reproduce that character across any new text with high consistency.

speaker: Tutorial Wizard
text: When you are ready, load Chapter Five: Directing with Instructions, and I will teach you how to write style prompts that get the performance you want every time.
